title: Executives’ Optimism in U.S. Economy Hits Three-Year Low
text:
Finance executives’ faith in the U.S. economy has reached a three-year low amid concerns over higher tariffs and economic uncertainty.

As optimism in the economy fades, so too do expectations for revenue growth, profit growth and expansion plans, according to finance chiefs, chief executives, controllers and other accountants at companies surveyed by the Association of International Certified Professional Accountants.

Forty-two percent of respondents were optimistic about the domestic economy’s outlook over the next 12 months, the lowest level since the third quarter of 2016, according to the association’s quarterly outlook survey, which polled 755 decision makers, mostly in the U.S.

The CPA Outlook Index, which weighs several areas of sentiment to gauge business activity and economic strength, showed year-over-year declines in expectations for every category, including prospects for revenue growth, profit, training and development, expansion plans and employment.

Forty-five percent of those surveyed cited global trade conflict as having a negative impact on their businesses over the past year. Of that group, 16% said they experienced significant or moderate impact from trade tensions.

“Whether this drop in optimism is a trend is a matter of whether global trade tensions, Brexit fears and unemployment will continue,” said Bob Sannerud, chairman of the organization’s Americas Regional Advisory Panel and chief financial officer of Life Link III, a Minneapolis-based air medical transportation company, in an interview.

U.S. businesses have suffered from the prolonged U.S.-China trade battle, which has prompted escalating tariffs.

According to the outlook survey, the biggest challenge facing companies in the third quarter is the availability of skilled personnel. But that challenge, which has topped the list for nine consecutive quarters, could be less of a concern if executives’ optimism continues to evaporate.

In the latest survey, optimism about employment dropped to the lowest level since the end of 2016. And 60% of respondents said they either had the appropriate number of employees or too many employees, the highest percentage since the end of 2017.

The second-biggest challenge, according to the survey, is the condition of the domestic economy, which had previously held the No. 6 spot for three consecutive quarters.
